subject: Re: junit 4 expected= subclass change
msgSnippet: ... are two ... I throw ... care ... I ve never seen an api that says when you do X, we will throw a random type of exception (though it will derive from Y)
messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Kent Beck" <kentb@...> wrote:
>
> Ben,
>
> Thank you for the feedback. We went around on this. It seems there
are two
> cases:
>
> 1) I am throwing an exception but I want to make it more specific so
I throw
> a subclass (Exception -> IllegalArgumentException). No catch clauses
care
> about the more-specific exception. If expected is looking for a precise
> class, a bunch of tests will break even though the code still works.

I've never seen an api that says "when you do X, we will throw a
random type of exception (though it will derive from Y)"

And if this is a common case, what about the case "We can throw either
an IllegalArgumentException or a FileNotFoundException but nothing
else". I think cases like #1 will still need to be done with the
manual patern (this is what NUnit pioneered with their expected
exception stuff, so I'd tend to agree with their choice).

> Either way you're going to get false results. One question is which
scenario
> is more common? Another is which scenario is more
dangerous/risky/expensive?

I'd argue that case 2 is much more common.

-- Ben
